description: Contemporary accounting and corporate financial reporting. Preparation, interpretation, and analysis of the earnings statement; the statement of financial position; and the statement of cash flows. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,300. Session A: June 3 - July 5.
title: Financial Accounting
subject: ACCT

description: Introduction to the study and writing of history, focusing on how African Americans fought for civil rights throughout the twentieth century. The civil rights movement placed in its historical context; African American freedom struggles placed in the larger narrative of U.S. history. 1 Credit. Tuition $3,300. Session A: June 3 - July 5.
title: The Civil Rights Movement
subject: AFAM

description: The history of slavery from the seventeenth-century development of racial slavery in the Americas through contemporary forms of enslavement and human trafficking. Theories on the origins of slavery; definitions of slavery; the slave societies of the Caribbean and North America; the transatlantic slave trade; nineteenth-century abolitionism and emancipations; the persistence of slavery in the twentieth century. 1 Credit. Tuition $3,300. Session B: July 8 - August 9.
title: History of American Slavery
subject: AFAM

description: Is there a link between social identity and crime?  What is the relationship among race, gender and perceptions of criminality?  What has been the impact of increasing social diversity on forms of social control, crime, and criminal justice policy?  This seminar explores these questions by examining the intersection of multiculturalism, crime, and the criminal justice system.  Students will be introduced to major, relevant criminological and sociological concepts, theories, and debates. Class discussions will address contemporary social problems such as racial profiling, disproportionate punishment, mass incarceration, and unequal justice.  Examples draw principally from the American but also from the British context, providing a comparative perspective. 1 Credit. Tuition $3,300. Session A: June 3 - July 5.
title: Multiculturalism and the Ordered Society
subject: AFAM

description: Offered in Ifrane and Rabat, Morocco. The Maghrib--Morocco, Algeria, Tunisia, and Libya--has historically been a critical frontier zone linking Africa, the Middle East, and Europe. This crossroads remains strategically important with sub-Saharan and North African migration, political Islam, Arab-Berber identity, terrorism and counter-terrorism, the Sahara question, and Mediterranean trade relationships being current international concerns.  This course provides a thorough overview of North African history, the legacies of colonialism and nationalism, political systems and opposition, Islam in North Africa, and the Maghrib in the twenty-first century. Students will meet with local experts, interact with Moroccan university students, and be able to do optional home stays with Moroccan families. Students are responsible for all travel expenses to and from Morocco, room and board costs in Morocco, and any other expenses beyond tuition. Application deadline: March 1. Enrollment limited. For further information visit the Yale Summer Session website. 2 Credits. Tuition $6,400. Course dates: June 1 - July 6.
title: Society and Politics of North Africa
subject: AFST

description: A survey of American literature and culture in the first half of the twentieth century. Works by Henry Adams, Hilda Doolittle, T.S. Eliot, William Faulkner, Ernest Hemingway, Zora Neale Hurston, Langston Hughes, Mina Loy, Ezra Pound, and Gertrude Stein. Please see online syllabus for readings for the first day of class. 1 Credit. Tuition $3,300. Session B: July 8 - August 9.
title: Modern American Literature, 1910-1952
subject: AMST

description: Introduction to the study and writing of history, focusing on how African Americans fought for civil rights throughout the twentieth century. The civil rights movement placed in its historical context; African American freedom struggles placed in the larger narrative of U.S. history. 1 Credit. Tuition $3,300. Session A: June 3 - July 5.
title: The Civil Rights Movement
subject: AMST

description: Is there a link between social identity and crime? What is the relationship among race, gender, and perceptions of criminality? What has been the impact of increasing social diversity on forms of social control, crime and criminal justice policy? This seminar explores these questions by examining the intersection of multiculturalism, crime and the criminal justice system. Students will be introduced to major, relevant criminological and sociological concepts, theories, and debates. Class discussions will address contemporary social problems such as racial profiling, disproportionate punishment, mass incarceration, and unequal justice. Examples draw principally from the American but also from the British context, providing a comparative perspective. 1 Credit. Tuition $3,300. Session A: June 3 - July 5.

description: A survey of the histories of both the Hollywood novel and films about Hollywood. Examination of the ways in which these two genres portray "the dream factory"-its past, present, and  future-as well as the way they interact. Books include Harry Leon Wilson's Merton at the Movies, Horace McCoy's They Shoot Horses, Don't They? and I Should Have Stayed Home, F. Scott Fitzgerald's The Last Tycoon, Budd Schulberg's What Makes Sammy Run, and Gore Vidal's Myra Breckenridge. Films include What Price Hollywood? A Star Is Born, Sunset Boulevard, In a Lonely Place, The Star, and The Player. 1 Credit. Tuition $3,300. Session A: June 3 - July 5.
short_title: The Hollywood Novel and the H...
title: The Hollywood Novel and the Hollywood Movie
subject: AMST

description: An examination of the cultural function of images in the making of collective identities and political transformation in the Americas. The course considers the visual field as a vehicle to address questions of gender, race, sexuality, violence, and social movements in the twentieth century. Study of theoretical works and a variety of still and moving images, including photography, artwork, film, mixed media, and performance. 1 Credit. Tuition $3,300. Session A: Jun 3 - July 5.
title: Contemporary Visual Culture in the Americas
subject: AMST

description: This course will examine the representation of American history on film and digital video, through the close analysis of American films from the beginning of the twentieth century to today. Topics will include: the Jazz Age, the Great Depression, World War II, the 1960s, Watergate, the Reagan Era, and post-9/11. Emphasis will be placed on the ways that films represent the historical moment from which they come. This course seeks to expand students' knowledge of the history of American film, culture, and society. Class screenings will feature such films as The Jazz Singer, It Happened One Night, The Best Years of Our Lives, Easy Rider, E.T., Do the Right Thing, and Traffic. 1 Credit. Tuition $3,300. Session B: July 8 - August 9.
title: Film, Video, and American History
subject: AMST

description: An introduction to the central ideas, methods, and debates that make up the anthropological study of human thought and behavior. Survey of dynamic ways of life in many different societies; outline of the ways anthropologists have tried to understand societies. Hands-on ethnographic research provides insight into how cultural anthropologists do what they doâwhat problems they encounter and what tools and techniques they use for research and analysis. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,300. Session B: July 8 - August 9.
title: Introduction to Cultural Anthropology
subject: ANTH

description: Introduction to human and primate evolution, primate behavior, and human biology. Topics include a review of principles of evolutionary and population biology, the evolution of primates and people, and current thinking about the evolution of human behavior. 1 Credit. Tuition $3,300. Session B: July 8 - August 9.
title: Introduction to Biological Anthropology
subject: ANTH

description: The prehistory of Mesopotamia, Egypt, and the Indus Valley, with a focus on important archaeological discoveries. Introduction to the basics of archaeological method and theory. Topics include human origins, the origins of agriculture, and the development of complex societies. 1 Credit. Tuition $3,300. Session A: June 3 - July 5.
title: Revealing the Past: Great Discoveries in Old World Archaeology
subject: ANTH

description: Hands-on introduction to forensic anthropology, using laboratory training, lectures, and case studies. Introduction to basic skeletal anatomy and to the use of recovered skeletal materials to assess a deceased individual's age, sex, height, ancestry, time of death, bone trauma, and disease. Additional topics include techniques for recovering human skeletal remains, reconstruction of faces, genetic identification, and medicolegal contexts of forensic anthropology. 1 Credit. Tuition $3,300. Session A: June 3 - July 5.
title: Forensic Anthropology
subject: ANTH

description: The archaeology of Mesopotamia, Egypt, and the Indus Valley from early agriculture to the earliest cities, states, and empires. Explores how these societies developed and why they collapsed. Earliest epics and contemporary ideologies, including the Bushes in Baghdad, examined in literature and film. Readings in translation. 1 Credit. Tuition $3,300. Session B: July 8 - August 9.
short_title: The Genesis and Collapse of O...
title: The Genesis and Collapse of Old World Civilizations
subject: ANTH

description: An exploration of the Himalayan region through film and ethnography. Visual and textual genres of storytelling and narration are used to examine topics such as adventure, caste, education, gender, ritual, and violence. Films and readings are drawn from Bhutan, northern India, Nepal, and Tibet. 1 Credit. Tuition $3,300. Session A: June 3 - July 5.
title: Himalaya through Film and Text
subject: ANTH

description: Global exploration of embodied ritual performance in Islam. Case studies range from ceremonies of the Mevlevi dervishes in Turkey to activist art in the context of U.S. detention and deportation of Muslims after 9/11. Development of practical skills in ethnographic research. 1 Credit. Tuition $3,300. Session A: June 3 - July 5.
title: Performance in Islamic Worlds
subject: ANTH

description: Offered in Singapore. Southeast Asia in Context is a five-week thematically based exploration of Southeast Asia's geographical and cultural diversity, which takes advantage of Singapore's position and character as a microcosm of this diversity. Blending classroom instruction on NUS Kent Ridge campus with hands-on fieldwork in Singapore, Cambodia, and Thailand, SEA in Context offers modules on Southeast Asia with anthropological, historical and archaeological concentrations.  The core module, SE2222: Southeast Asia In Context provides a broad overview of Southeast Asia from a historical, sociological and anthropological perspective. Its partner module,  SE2880A: Southeast Asia's Cultural Mosaic, will equip students with the analytical tools for the comparative study of society and culture, and features a ten-day field trip to  various religious, cultural, and archaeological sites in Cambodia and Thailand. Both modules deploy "context-based" learning by combining in-class instruction at NUS campus with local and regional hands-on experience of Southeast Asian life. Students are responsible for all travel expenses to and from Singapore, costs of room and board, and all other expenses beyond tuition. Application deadline: March 1. Enrollment limited. For further information visit the Yale Summer Session website. 1 Yale Credit and 1 NUS Credit. Tuition $4,100. Program fee: $1,200. Course dates: June 21 - July 23.
title: Southeast Asia in Context
subject: ANTH

description: Environmental and ecological approaches to anthropology, and anthropological approaches to environmental issues. How humans use the environment. Ways in which the environment has become a principal field of contestation and struggle. Readings in ecological anthropology, cultural ecology, political ecology, and the anthropology of environment and development as well as film screenings. This course may serve as a good introduction for ANTH 382/EVST 345. 1 Credit. Tuition $3,300. Session A: June 3 - July 5.
title: Introduction to Environmental Anthropology
subject: ANTH

description: Offered in Tokyo. Animation (anime) and graphic novels (manga) in twentieth-century Japan. Focus on the social and historical context of the production and consumption of manga and anime. Explore gender and sexuality through these media and in Japanese popular culture. Create your own anime or manga short. No knowledge of Japanese required. Students are responsible for all travel expenses to and from Japan, costs of room and board, and all other expenses beyond tuition. Enrollment limited. Application deadline: March 1. For further information visit the Yale Summer Session website. 2 Credits. Tuition $6,400. Course Dates: July 6 - August 10.
title: Anime and Manga
subject: ANTH

description: Approaches religion as a system of symbols, rituals, and beliefs with an eye to classical and contemporary anthropological theory. Addresses broad questions about the roles religion plays in human life in relation to people's conceptions of worldviews and the supernatural. Examines the historical and regional contexts of religious formations around the world and the relationship between religion and modernization. Debates regarding religious violence, secularism, and atheism are also covered. 1 Credit. Tuition $3,300. Session A: June 3 - July 5.
title: Anthropology of Religion
subject: ANTH

description: Offered in Mumbai, India. Students will have the opportunity to study and be in class with local students from St. Xavier's University. Critical engagement with contemporary Indian politics, society, culture, and religion through an intensive and immersive study in Mumbai, one of the largest cities in the world. Topics include: urban poverty, urban town planning, housing problems, sanitation, cultural politics, religious and sectarian violence, caste politics, class ghettoization, communal violence, migration, urban-rural divide, and Bollywood and popular culture. Students are responsible for all travel expenses to and from India, costs of room and board, and all other expenses beyond tuition. Application deadline: March 1. Enrollment limited. For more information visit the Yale Summer Session website. 2 Credits. Tuition $6,400. Course dates: June 1 - July 5.
title: Bombay: City, Society and Culture
subject: ANTH

description: Seminar that examines the science behind selected advances in modern technology. Focus on the scientific and contextual basis of each advance, as well as the technology's resulting impact on society. Student groups present case studies, with topics developed by the participants in collaboration with the instructor. Intended for nonâscience majors. Enrollment limited. 1 Credit. Tuition $3,300. Session A: June 3 - July 5.
title: Science of Modern Technology
subject: APHY

description: Seminar that covers the technology, use, and impact of energy on the environment, climate, security, and the economy. Emphasis on what drives people's choices and the effects of those choices. Prerequisite: a strong background in high school physics, chemistry, and mathematics. 1 Credit. Tuition $3,300. Session B: July 8 - August 9.
title: Energy, Technology and Society
subject: APHY

description: Development of a basic knowledge of Modern Standard Arabic through a comprehensive and integrated method emphasizing reading, writing, speaking, comprehension, grammar, and vocabulary acquisition. description: Offered in Beijing, China. In this joint studio with third-year students from Tsinghua University's School of Architecture, students will explore the programmatic, situational, and tectonic range of the Chinese courtyard house typology (the fundamental module of pre-1949 Chinese architecture and urbanism). The elasticity and persistence of this type will be explored in a series of radically different sites: a central Beijing hutong, a chain of rural villages in Shanxi Province, and the Forbidden City. Working in teams, students will use survey, analysis, and design exercises to engage each location. A final project will ask them to synthesize these diverse efforts (and sites) into a contemporary take on the typology. Must be taken in conjunction with ARCH S241. Prerequisite: an introductory course in architecture or drawing. Students are responsible for all travel expenses to and from China, costs of room and board, and all other expenses beyond tuition. Enrollment limited. Application deadline: March 1. For further information visit the Yale Summer Session website. 1 Credit. Tuition $3,200. Course Dates: June 23 - August 3.
title: The Chinese House from Courtyard to City
subject: ARCH

description: Offered in Beijing, China. Major themes in the history and theory of the Chinese built environment will be explored in relation to the typology of the Chinese house. Through a combination of readings, lectures, group and individual site visits, presentations, and reports the Chinese house will be used as an armature for a more general introduction to the history, culture, and evolution of Chinese architecture, gardens, and urbanism. Must be taken in conjunction with ARCH S240. Students are responsible for all travel expenses to and from China, costs of room and board, and all other expenses beyond tuition. Enrollment limited. Application deadline: March 1. For further information visit the Yale Summer Session website. 1 Credit. Tuition $3,200. Course Dates: June 23 - August 3.
title: Chinese Landscape, Architecture and Urbanism
subject: ARCH

description: Key developments in modern architecture from 1900 to the present. Work of some of the key figures of American modernism, including Frank Lloyd Wright, Louis Kahn, Eero Saarinen, and Robert Venturi/Denise Scott Brown will be discussed. The seminar pays particular attention to how formal and spatial techniques shape architectural and urban experience. Includes local archive and museum visits, as well as field trips to view the extraordinary examples of modern architecture and urbanism. 1 Credit. Tuition $3,300. Session A: June 3 - July 5.
title: Modern Architecture
subject: ARCH

description: The development of design philosophies and methodologies in Japanese architecture over the last century. The processes of urbanization and of finding cultural identity as forces that shaped architectural developments. Specific projects and architects used as case studies. Screenings and discussion of Japanese films, with attention to their spatial, social, and cultural contexts. Recommended preparation: an introductory course in the history of art and architecture. 1 Credit. Tuition $3,300. Session B: July 8 - August 9.
title: Architecture and Urbanism of Modern Japan
subject: ARCH

description: An introduction to drawing, emphasizing pictorial syntax and the articulation of space. Class work is based on observational study. Assigned projects address fundamental technical and conceptual problems suggested by historical and recent artistic practice. No prior drawing experience necessary. Enrollment limited to 20 students. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,500. Session B: July 8 - August 9.
title: Basic Drawing
subject: ART

description: Exploration of the transition of photographic processes and techniques into digital formats. A range of tools are presented including scanning, digital cameras, retouching, color correction, basic composition, and inkjet printing. Students produce original work throughout the technical component of the class. After mastering the basics, students work toward the completion of a final project, and the focus of the remaining classes is on critiques. Throughout the term, lectures and presentations raise critical issues concerning the impact of digital applications and by-products on the medium of photography. Students must have access to a digital camera and bring it to class. Enrollment limited to 16 students. 1 Credit. Tuition $3,500. Session B: July 8 - August 9.
title: Introduction to Digital Photography
subject: ART

description: A studio introduction to typographic communication on the Internet. Students will conceive, design, and build a website with a content management system. The relationship between web server, web browser, content author, graphic designer, and user will be emphasized as both technical issues and aesthetic opportunities. Sustainability and evolution of a website over time is emphasized. HTML, CSS, image preparation, and basics of PHP will be taught utilizing the computer facilities at the Yale School of Art. No previous knowledge necessary. Enrollment limited to 16 students. 1 Credit. Tuition $3,500. Session B: July 8 - August 9.
title: Introduction to Interactive Design: World Wide Web
subject: ART

description: Introduction to the principles, history, and practice of animation in visual art and film. With a primary focus on production, this course utilizes historical and theoretical developments in twentieth- and twenty-first-century animation as a framework for making digital animation. Production focuses primarily on digital stop-animation and compositing, as well as 2D and 3D computer-generated animation. Students gain an understanding of the principles of animation and develop fundamental skill-sets in Apple Final Cut Pro, Adobe After Effects, and Autodesk Maya 2012. 1 Credit. Tuition $3,500. Session B: July 8 - August 9.
title: Principles of Animation
subject: ART

description: For non-science majors. An introduction to stars and planetary systems. Topics include the solar system and extrasolar planets, planet and star formation, and the evolution of stars from birth to death. No prerequisite other than a working knowledge of elementary algebra. 1 Credit. Tuition $3,300. Session A: June 3 - July 5.
title: Planets and Stars
subject: ASTR

description: A nontechnical introduction to stellar populations and the structure and evolution of the Milky Way galaxy; external galaxies, radio galaxies, and quasars; cosmology and the expanding universe. No prerequisite other than a working knowledge of elementary algebra. 1 Credit. Tuition $3,300. Session B: July 8 - August 9.
title: Galaxies and the Universe
subject: ASTR

description: Offered in Santiago, Chile. This six-week course will be held at the University of Chile as part of the Yale-University of Chile collaboration in astronomy and astrophysics education and research. The course is an introduction to astrophysics and to ground-based observing techniques. Extensive observing using research facilities at the Cerro Calan and Cerro Tololo Observatories. Field trips to other major Andean observatories. Students will be able to view the sky through premier telescopes at the clearest observational site in the Southern Hemisphere.  Students are responsible for all travel expenses to and from Santiago, costs of room and board, and all other expenses beyond tuition. Application deadline: March 1. Enrollment limited. Prerequisite: Physics 180 or equivalent. For further information visit the Yale Summer Session website. 1 Credit. Tuition $3,300. Course Dates: June 2 - July 13.
title: Introduction to Observational Astrophysics
subject: ASTR

description: Introduction to the study of life at the molecular level and to cell biology and membrane physiology. Topics include the three-dimensional structures and function of large biological molecules, the human genome, the design of antiviral drugs to treat HIV/AIDS, organization and functional properties of biological membranes, membrane physiology and signaling, rough endoplasmic reticulum and synthesis of membrane/secretory membrane proteins, endocytosis, the cytoskeleton, and cell division. Covers the material of BIOL 101 and 102, the first half of the yearlong introductory biology sequence. Followed in the summer by BIOL S-106. Enrollment limited. 1 Credit. Tuition $3,300. Session A: June 3 - July 5.
title: Biochemistry, Biophysics, and Cell Biology
subject: BIOL

description: Introduction to genes, genetics, developmental biology, ecology, evolutionary biology, animal behavior, and the history of life. How genes control development and disease; Mendel's rules; examples of organ physiology; evolutionary transitions and natural selection; adaptation at genic, chromosomal, cellular, organismal, and supra-organismal levels; distributional and social consequences of particular suites of organismal adaptations. Covers the material of BIOL 103 and 104, the second half of the yearlong introductory biology sequence. Prerequisite: BIOL 101 and 102 or BIOL S-105. Enrollment limited. 1 Credit. Tuition $3,300. Session B: July 8 - August 9.
title: Genes, Ecology, and Evolutionary Biology
subject: BIOL

description: This intensive seven-week summer course provides a comprehensive introduction to the use of statistics in the fields of epidemiology, public health, and clinical research. Students gain experience conducting and interpreting a broad range of statistical analyses. Topics include descriptive statistics, probability distributions, parameter estimation, hypothesis testing, sampling, analysis of variance, nonparametric tests, and linear regression. Through weekly computer laboratory sessions, students become familiar with the SAS statistical software package.
requirements: Not open to students in the traditional two-year M.P.H. program.
title: Accelerated Biostatistics
subject: BIS

description: The development of the art academy in England from the early decades of the eighteenth century to the mid-nineteenth century. The academy’s role in the education of artists, the dissemination of art theory, and the promotion of the public exhibition; its influence on the careers of artists such as William Hogarth, Joshua Reynolds, Thomas Gainsborough, Richard Wilson, Johan Zoffany, William Blake, John Constable, and J. M. W. Turner. The relative importance of history painting, portraiture, landscape, and genre painting within the evolving academic hierarchy.

description: This intensive seven-week summer course provides students with an introduction to social and behavioral science issues that influence patterns of health and health care delivery. The focus is on the integration of biomedical, social, psychological, and behavioral factors that must be taken into consideration when public health initiatives are developed and implemented. This course emphasizes the integration of research from the social and behavioral sciences with epidemiology and biomedical sciences.
requirements: Not open to students in the traditional two-year M.P.H. program.
title: Accelerated Social and Behavioral Foundations of Health
subject: CDE

description: This intensive seven-week summer course provides a comprehensive overview of epidemiologic concepts and methods. Topics include measurement of disease and association, descriptive epidemiology study design (including randomized and non-randomized controlled trials, cohort studies, case-control studies, cross-sectional studies, and ecologic studies), screening principles, reliability and validity, bias, confounding, and effect modification. After completing this course, students are able to calculate and interpret epidemiologic parameters, identify the strengths and weaknesses of various study designs, and apply the principles and methods of epidemiology to the design and analysis of new studies.
requirements: Not open to students in the traditional two-year M.P.H. program.
title: Accelerated Epidemiology
subject: CDE

description: A study of the myths of Greek and Roman gods and heroes. The literary forms, historical contexts, and cultural uses of classical mythologies. Subsequent development and reception of these myths in various cultures and media from the Renaissance to the present. Analyses of these myths over the course of the past two centuries. 1 Credit. Tuition $3,300. Session A: June 3 - July 5.
title: Classical Mythologies
subject: CLCV

description: Introduction to the construction and performance of heroism in Greek tragic drama, with close reading of selected plays in translation. Focus on the sagas of the House of Atreus and Oedipus. Defining the tragic hero; the tragic flaw; characterization and stagecraft; playwrights' responses to the Homeric hero; and modern responses to Greek tragedy. Includes screenings of film adaptations of the plays. 1 Credit. Tuition $3,300. Session A: June 3 - July 5.
short_title: The Tragic Hero in Greek Drama
title: The Tragic Hero in Greek Drama
subject: CLSS

description: An exploration of the myriad ways in which law and technology intersect, with a special focus on broadband, the Internet, and how telecommunications law has evolved to where it is today. Topics include the breakup of the Bell system monopoly, Wi-Fi, FCC regulation of broadband and the Internet, voice over Internet protocol, smartphones, and mobile networks. No previous experience with computers or law necessary. 1 Credit. Tuition $3,300. Session A: June 3 - July 5.
title: Internet and Telecommunications Law
subject: CPSC

description: Offered in Prague, Czech Republic. Introduction to Czech intellectual culture through contemporary film, fiction, art, language, and film-making practicum (with guest lectures by prominent economic and cultural leaders). Emphasis on Kafka's influence on today's Prague. Works include films by Milos Forman (Fireman's Ball), Jan Kadar (Shop on the Main Street), Jan Sverak (Kolya), and Jan Hrebejk (Divided We Fall), and readings by Franz Kafka, Milan Kundera, Bohumil Hrabal, Vaclav Havel, and Arnost Lustig. Includes a four-day film-making practicum: under the supervision of cinematographers Gary Griffin, Josef Lustig and Alice Arnold students shoot two or three short films based on their screenplays written in class. A comprehensive introduction to basic Czech (no language prerequisites required) is an integral cultural part of the course. Students performing exceptionally in Czech language may qualify for placement above L1 during the 2013-14 academic year. Students choose FILM or CZEC credit. Students are responsible for all travel expenses to and from Prague, costs of room and board, and all other expenses beyond tuition. Application deadline: March 1. Enrollment limited. For further information view the Yale Summer Session website. 2 Credits. Tuition $6,400. Course dates: July 4 - August 10.
title: In Kafka's Spirit: Prague Film and Fiction
subject: CZEC

description: Application of economic principles to the study of the U.S. health care system. Emphasis on basic principles about the structure of the U.S. system, current problems, proposed solutions, and the context of health policy making and politics. description: An overview of the Chinese economy, with attention to its rapid growth in the past two decades and its current challenges. The cultural and political background of the economy, China's market transition, manufacturing and financial sectors, foreign trade, foreign direct investment and technology transfer, and the reform of state-owned enterprises. Prerequisite: Introductory economics.  1 Credit. Tuition $3,300. Session B: July 8-August 9.

description: Offered in Paris, France. Parties engaging in economic exchange often organize their relationships through contracts and other private legal structures. In this course we will study the organization of exchange and the body of law and private institutions that govern and influence its structure. The course curriculum develops through a substantive theoretical component and a practical component, with on-site modules at the International Court of Commercial Arbitration in Paris. A comparative legal and institutional approach will be maintained throughout. Students are responsible for all travel expenses to and from Paris, costs of room and board, and all other expenses beyond tuition. Application deadline: March 1. Enrollment limited. Prerequisite: MATH 112, ECON 121, or permission of instructor. For further information visit the Yale Summer Session website. 2 Credits. Tuition $6,400. Course Dates: June 21 - July 27.

description: Corruption, a manifestation of the principal-agent problem, is an obstacle to economic efficiency. This course examines the economic, cultural, and political causes and consequences of corruption; cross-country comparisons of corruption levels; and examples of successful reforms and policies to combat corruption in bureaucracy and business. Students will complete a documented research project as part of the course. Prerequisite: ECON 108a or b, 110a, or 115a or b, or equivalent. 1 Credit. Tuition $3,300. Session B: July 8 - August 9.
title: The Economics of Corruption
subject: ECON

description: This is a course on efficiency: the First and Second Welfare Theorems, in simple general equilibrium models of competitive markets and market failures, where the welfare theorems do not hold, that is, externalities, public goods, and monopoly pricing. In particular, we consider and compare the relative merits of the Kaldor-Hicks compensation principle in partial equilibrium analysis and the Pareto principle in general equilibrium analysis. Prerequisites: ECON 121 and MATH 112. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,300. Session A: June 3 - July 5.
title: Welfare Economics and Equality
subject: ECON

description: Recent developments in international economics. Trade policy and market structure; the economics of trading blocs such as the EU and NAFTA; the economic consequences of continued U.S. external deficits; globalization and inequality; exchange rates, interest rates, and volatility; speculative capital flows and exchange rate policies; and financial crises and the prospects for the European Monetary Union. Prerequisites: intermediate microeconomics and macroeconomics or equivalents. 1 Credit. Tuition $3,300. Session A: June 3 - July 5.
title: Topics in International Economics
subject: ECON

description: An introduction to information transmission and storage and their impact on society. Technological issues and trade-offs that affect the design of digital systems. Elementary circuits and computer logic, sensors and actuators, signal processing and design for data transmission, and information transmission on the World Wide Web. Projects include analysis and design using Matlab. Intended for students in the humanities and social sciences and for freshmen considering a major in electrical engineering. No prerequisite other than a working knowledge of algebra. 1 Credit. Tuition $3,300. Session B: July 8 - August 9.

description: Seminar that examines the science behind selected advances in modern technology. Focus on the scientific and contextual basis of each advance, as well as the technology's resulting impact on society. Student groups present case studies, with topics developed by the participants in collaboration with the instructor. Intended for non-science majors. Enrollment limited. 1 Credit. Tuition $3,300. description: Quantitative reasoning applied to evaluation of physical formulas and to interpretation of actual data. Concepts illustrated with models that simulate random data.  Statistical measures predict accuracy of analytic results. Analysis ranges from paper-and-pencil and scientific calculator to Excel spreadsheets. Case studies include societal problems involving technological issues, life expectancy, and predicting Olympic gold medal performance. 1 Credit. Tuition $3,300. Session A: June 3 - July 5.

description: Seminar that covers the technology, use, and impact of energy on the environment, climate, security, and the economy. Session B: July 8 - August 9.
title: Energy, Technology and Society
subject: ENAS

description: An introduction to academic argument and well-reasoned analysis, using a broad spectrum of nonfiction prose. Intensive instruction and practice in writing argumentative essays. Enrollment limited to 15. 1 Credit. Tuition $3,300. Offered in Session A (CRN 30083)and Session B (CRNs 30085 and 30086). Session A: June 3 - July 5, Session B: July 8 - August 9.

description: Uses literature to explore the nature and significance of a humorous approach to the world. Special emphasis on learning to write analytical arguments about fiction, poetry, drama, and film. Writers include William Shakespeare, Aphra Behn, Jonathan Swift, Francois Rabelais, Oscar Wilde, Mark Twain, Kurt Vonnegut, Lorrie Moore, and others. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,300. Session A: June 3 - July 5.
title: Writing About Literature I
subject: ENGL

description: Close study of selected works of nonfiction prepares students to become critical readers and to apply professionals' strategies to their own writing. Readings from such authors as Joan Didion, Malcolm Gladwell, Maxine Hong Kingston, George Orwell, Jonathan Swift, Henry David Thoreau, Tom Wolfe, Alice Walker, among others. Written assignments, involving frequent revision, include autobiography, portraiture, nature writing, cultural critique, and formal argument. ENGL S120 is an intensive course designed for students who are confident readers and writers of English. It is recommended that students who have not completed an introductory college-level writing course take ENGL S114 instead. Enrollment limited to 15. 1 Credit. Tuition $3,300. Offered in Session A (CRN 30088) and Session B (CRN 30089). Session A: June 3 - July 5,  Session B: July 8 - August 9.
title: Reading and Writing the Modern Essay
subject: ENGL

description: An introduction to the diversity and the continuity of the English language tradition through close reading of four poets from the fourteenth through the seventeenth centuries, Chaucer, Spenser, Shakespeare, and Donne. Emphasis on developing skills of literary interpretation and critical writing. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,300. Session B: July 8 - August 9.
title: Major English Poets
subject: ENGL

description: This course serves as both an introduction to as well as an exploration of American literature from the nineteenth century to the present. We will ask many questions of these texts, not the least of which is: what do we mean when we say "American?" Given the wide range of the body of work that comprises American literature, however, we will also periodically ask in passing what we mean by "literature" so as to consider what roles the literary plays in creating and shaping the possibilities of social imagination, private and public discourse, as well as one's own identity. Emphasis on analytical reading, critical writing, and class discussions. Authors include Melville, Poe, Hawthorne, Whitman, Dickinson, Barnes, Toomer, H. Crane, W. C. Williams, L. Hughes, and M. Robinson. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,300. Session A: June 3 - July 5.
title: Readings in American Literature
subject: ENGL

description: A course that combines both fiction and nonfiction writing, conducted as a workshop. The focus will be on elements common to all storytelling,among them, narrative development, voice, and clarity of language and thought. Students will have the opportunity to write short fiction, memoir, and journalistic nonfiction. They may concentrate in one genre, or, if they wish, experiment with genres new to them. A brief writing sample in the course subject area is required and should be submitted with your application. Enrollment limited to 15. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,300. Session B: July 8 - August 9.
title: Narrative Writing: A Fiction and Nonfiction Workshop
subject: ENGL

description: A study of ten comedies and romances, their festivities and their reservations. Extensive practice in writing critical essays. Students should come to the first class having read A Midsummer Night's Dream. (The Signet edition is preferred.) Selections from filmed productions of the plays are screened semiweekly, and students are asked to attend a number of these screenings. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,300. Session B: July 8 - August 9.
title: Shakespeare: Comedies and Romances
subject: ENGL

title: ShakespeareHistories&Tragedies

description: An in-depth reading of James Joyces twentieth-century epic Ulysses, one of the primary texts of literary modernism.  Close analysis of Joyce's prose, including examination of its devices and charting the correspondences and cross-references so important to an understanding of the novel.  1 Credit.  Tuition: $3,300.  Session B: July 8 - August 9.
title: James Joyce's Ulysses
subject: ENGL

description: Offered online. A study of Milton's major poetry, with attention to his relation to the cultural, social, and political struggles of the Puritan Revolution. Students will watch or listen to pre-recorded lectures and will meet online for biweekly seminar discussions. Satisfies pre-1800 requirement. Enrollment limited. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,300. Technology fee: $85. Session A: June 3 - July 5.
title: Milton
subject: ENGL

description: A survey of American literature and culture in the first half of the twentieth century. Works by Henry Adams, Hilda Doolittle, T.S. Eliot, William Faulkner, Ernest Hemingway, Zora Neale Hurston, Langston Hughes, Mina Loy, Ezra Pound, and Gertrude Stein. Please see online syllabus for readings for the first day of class. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,300. Session B: July 8 - August 9.
title: Modern American Literature, 1910-1952
subject: ENGL

description: In-depth reading and discussion of major twentieth-century American playwrights, including Eugene O'Neill, Thornton Wilder, Zora Neale Hurston, Tennessee Williams, Arthur Miller, Edward Albee, David Mamet, and Suzan-Lori Parks. 1 Credit. Tuition $3,300. Session A: June 3 - July 5.
title: Modern American Drama
subject: ENGL

description: Study of the Bible as a literature-as a collection of works exhibiting a variety of attitudes toward the conflicting claims of tradition and originality, historicity and literariness. For Yale College English majors, the course can fulfill a pre-1800 credit upon completion of supplementary assignments in the language of the King James Bible. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,300. Session A: June 3 - July 5.
title: The Bible as Literature
subject: ENGL

description: Techniques of in-depth reporting, ranging from interviews and document research to journalistic storytelling; the evolution of "muckraking" in the United States; and the ethical, philosophical, and political issues raised by such work. Improvement of the students' practical research and narrative skills through weekly assignments and a term-long writing project. Designed equally for those with journalistic experience and for those with skills in other arenas. Writing sample of a piece of journalism or an essay of five pages revealing research and writing skills is required and should be submitted with your application. Enrollment limited to 15. 1 Credit. Tuition $3,300. Session A: June 3 - July 5.
title: Investigative Journalism
subject: ENGL

description: An advanced workshop for writers who want to review the performing arts for newspapers, magazines, and other media. Weekly assignments to review screenings and performances, many of which will be part of New Haven's International Festival of Arts and Ideas. Class trip to New York City to review a theater production. A brief writing sample in the course subject area is required and should be submitted with your application. Enrollment limited to 15. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,300. Session A: June 3 - July 5.
title: Reviewing Film, Theater, Music, and Dance
subject: ENGL

description: Environmental sustainability and the role of green energy in mitigating the impact of greenhouse gases and global warming. Solar thermal, solar photovoltaic, wind, biofuel, hydro, geothermal, and nuclear power; ocean thermal energy conversion and harvesting of tidal power. System-level performance, overall efficiency, cost, and environmental impact of integrated green energy systems. Laboratory experiments on wind-based electricity generation, solar-powered water electrolyzers for hydrogen production, and hydrogen-powered fuel cells. 1 Credit. Tuition $3,300. Session A: June 3 - July 5.
title: Introduction to Green Energy
subject: ENVE

description: Offered online. Environmental sustainability and the role of green energy in mitigating the impact of greenhouse gases and global warming. Solar thermal, solar photovoltaic, wind, biofuel, hydro, geothermal, and nuclear power; ocean thermal energy conversion and harvesting of tidal power. System-level performance, overall efficiency, cost, and environmental impact of integrated green energy systems. Enrollment limited. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,300. Technology fee: $85. Session B: July 8 - August 9.
title: Introduction to Green Energy
subject: ENVE

description: Introduction to contemporary philosophical debate about the nature of lies and deception. Definitions of lying and deception, including whether all lies necessarily aim to deceive; moral justifications for lying and deceit and their counterarguments; ways in which the moral arguments against deception of others can apply to self-deception. Recommended preparation: EP&E 215 or a course in political philosophy. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,300. Session A: June 3 - July 5.
title: Lies and Deception
subject: EP&E

description: Questions about human responsibilities for the environment. Wilderness protection, sustainability, preservation of species, the costs of fighting global warming, and humans' right to a healthy environment. Attention to analytical and argumentative skills required in legal and environmental advocacy. 1 Credit. Tuition $3,300. Session B: July 8 - August 9.
title: Environmental Ethics
subject: EP&E

description: The Internship is a degree requirement that is completed in the summer between the first and second academic years. Students work with their faculty advisers and the Office of Career Services to identify suitable placements, which include medical care facilities, community agencies, research projects, laboratories, and other sites engaged in public health activities. The internship experience often serves as a basis for the M.P.H. thesis. The internship is displayed on the transcript with a grade of "S" (Satisfactory) upon completion. A course unit is not given for the summer internship.
requirements: All students must complete a Summer Internship with the exception of those in the Advanced Professional M.P.H. Program. The Summer Internship may be used to complete the Public Health Practice requirement with prior approval from the Office of Community Health.
title: Summer Internship
subject: EPH

description: This course is part of the International Alliance of Research Universities' Global Summer Program. For IARU/GSP students only. Yale students may apply for a limited number of spaces. Partial tuition scholarships available. Sustainable development as it relates to institutional change, decision-making processes, and systems thinking.  Throughout the course we will explore the question of how organizations have the capacity to advance principles of sustainable development in their operational functions, mission, and growth. The students will engage with Yale as a Living Laboratory throughout the course as well as visit one to two peer institutions in the region. Course lectures and discussions will draw from Yale's sustainability commitments to: reduce greenhouse gas emissions, implement a transportation demand management system, serve sustainable and local food in the residential colleges, build sustainable buildings, integrate sustainability into the master plan framework, reduce waste and manage the urban campus via an ecosystem services framework. 1 Credit. Tuition $3,300. Course dates: July 1 - August 9.
title: Sustainability and Institutions
subject: EVST

description: Environmental and ecological approaches to anthropology, and anthropological approaches to environmental issues. How humans use the environment. Ways in which the environment has become a principal field of contestation and struggle. Readings in ecological anthropology, cultural ecology, political ecology, and the anthropology of environment and development. 1 Credit. Tuition $3,300. Session A: June 3 - July 5.
title: Introduction to Environmental Anthropology
subject: EVST

description: Offered in Prague, Czech Republic. An intensive, hands-on exploration of film history, theory, and practice, offered in partnership with FAMU, the national film and television academy of the Czech Republic, Europe's top film school. During each week of the program students will learn the theory, tools, and techniques that defined a period in film history, and acquire a new set of practical skills--from operating a 16 mm film camera to recording dialogue to lighting a set--which they will apply in the production of a weekly film project. During the third week of the program, students will travel to the beautiful spa town of Karlovy Vary (Carlsbad) to attend the world-renowned Karlovy Vary International Film Festival. Instructors for the program will include Pavel Jech, the dean of FAMU, and Michal Bregant, the Director of the National Film Archive of the Czech Republic. The program includes a two-week minicourse in Czech language and culture. All instruction is in English. Enrollment limited to 16. Application deadline: March 1. For further information visit the Yale Summer Session website. 1 Yale Credit: Tuition: $3,300. 1 FAMU Credit: Tuition $3,750. Total tuition is $7,050. Course dates: June 16 - July 20.
title: The Yale Summer Film Institute at FAMU
subject: FILM

description: Offered in Paris, France. Paris is the cultural capital of cinema. No city has been celebrated in film as frequently and as lovingly as Paris. This course is an introduction to French cinema and culture from 1915 to the present, which focuses on the mystery, romance, youth, and consumerism of Paris. The class will explore Parisian neighborhoods on city walks, visit two preeminent French cinema institutions (the Cinematheque Francaise and the Institut Lumiere) and view films together. These films will include Breathless, La Haine, and Amelie. All readings will be in English, with further, optional readings in French. All films are subtitled in English. Students are responsible for all travel expenses to and from Paris, costs of room and board, and all other expenses beyond tuition. Application deadline: March 1. Enrollment limited. For further information visit the Yale Summer Session website. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,300. Course dates: July 6 - August 10.
title: Paris and the Cinema
subject: FILM

description: Offered in Siena, Italy. This five-week course combines beginning Italian with a course in English on Italian cinema focusing on Tuscany. Students will learn Italian through classes and full-immersion in the study-abroad experience (including a homestay), and will explore the representation of Tuscany through the screening and close analysis of films where the Tuscan setting has been elevated to the level of a primary thematic concern. Among the films to be considered are Room with a View, Night of the Shooting Stars, The First Beautiful Thing, Tea with Mussolini, The Sky Is Falling, Life Is Beautiful, Sandra, Mar nero, Good Morning Babylon, Fiorile, and the Florentine episode of Paisa. Students who wish to continue with Italian are required to take a placement test in order to place into ITAL 120. Students may petition for one HU credit. Students are responsible for all travel expenses to and from Siena, room and board costs in Italy, and any other expenses beyond tuition. Application deadline: March 1. Enrollment limited. For further information visit the Yale Summer Session website. 2 Credits. Tuition $6,400. Course dates: June 22 - July 27.
title: Italian Language and Cinema in Tuscany
subject: FILM

description: A survey of the histories of both the Hollywood novel and films about Hollywood. Examination of the ways in which these two genres portray "the dream factory"-its past, present, and future-as well as the way they interact. Books include Harry Leon Wilson's Merton at the Movies, Horace McCoy's They Shoot Horses, Don't They? and I Should Have Stayed Home, F. Scott Fitzgerald's The Last Tycoon, Budd Schulberg's What Makes Sammy Run, and Gore Vidal's Myra Breckenridge. Films include What Price Hollywood? A Star Is Born, Sunset Boulevard, In a Lonely Place, The Star,and The Player. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,300. Session A: June 3 - July 5.
short_title: The Hollywood Novel and the H...
title: The Hollywood Novel and the Hollywood Movie
subject: FILM

description: Exploration of the contemporary Hollywood film industry. Introduction to the close analysis of film sequences. Central components of a Hollywood production, such as script, director, star, and genre. Aspects of the industry, including production, distribution, and exhibition. Ingredients of blockbuster success; why some films fail catastrophically. Case studies pair current films with historical ones. Includes two screenings per week. 1 Credit. Tuition $3,300. Session A: June 3 - July 5.
title: The Blockbuster and the Bomb
subject: FILM

description: Exploration of Chinese film from 1949 to the present. State policies, filmmaking trends, representative filmmakers and films, and the state of the industry. No previous knowledge of Chinese language or film required. 1 Credit. Tuition $3,300. Session B: July 8 - August 9.
title: Chinese Film Studies
subject: FILM

description: An intensive, comprehensive hands-on workshop in which the problems and aesthetics of filmmaking are studied in practice as well as theory. Students learn the narrative film form and its collaborative nature by participating in the production process. By screening classic narrative masterpieces they will gain a sense of the medium's historical and aesthetic context, as well as develop a common vocabulary and point of reference with their fellow collaborators. The students will begin with seminars, readings, and exercises that cover working with actors, script analysis, producing, camera, lighting, sound, and editing and then move on to an actual production where as a group they make a short HD movie. Film professionals from various areas of expertise instruct and guide students in the application of industry standards to the exercises and projects. The course is fully integrated with FILM S203 to provide filmmakers with a pool of acting talent and enable students to move beyond the technological requirements of the medium. This workshop requires a full daily commitment of the student's time, including 5 hours of classroom instruction, 2 hours of screenings, 1-2 hours of reading homework and workshop projects outside of class time and on weekends.  Enrollment limited to 16. For students in college or beyond only. 2 Credits. Tuition $6,400. Dates: June 10 - July 19.
title: Intensive Filmmaking Workshop
subject: FILM

description: An intensive, full-time, hands-on workshop that is fully integrated with the Intensive Filmmaking Workshop (Film S202) and allows the student actor to solve the artistic problems and technical challenges of film acting. Students begin with exercises that acclimate them to the tenets of good acting under the pressures and demands of the filmic medium. Then, with rehearsed scene work, they learn the technical language of cinema and participate in various filmmaking practices. Their knowledge and techniques are tested by acting in one or more of the films produced by the Intensive Filmmaking Workshop. With the Filmmaking Workshop, the students screen classic narrative masterpieces nightly in order to gain a sense of the medium's historical and aesthetic context as well as to develop a common vocabulary and point of reference with fellow collaborators. Screenings, readings, and rehearsals supplement practical application. Daily commitments include, but are not limited to: 3-5 hours daily of classroom instruction, 2.5 hours of nightly screenings, 1-3 hours daily reading, rehearsal and shooting sessions outside of classroom time and on weekends. Enrollment limited to 16. For students in college or beyond only. 2 Credits. Tuition $6,400. Dates: June 10 - July 19.
title: Acting in Film
subject: FILM

description: Introduction to critical skills for understanding and producing digital films with smartphone cameras. Ways in which the phone camera extends the director's opportunities for new kinds of visual narrative. Adaptation of techniques such as collage, montage, and assemblage from previous generations of filmmakers. Students create their own short-form digital films and are required to have access to a smartphone with a camera. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,300. Session A: June 3 - July 5.
title: Experimental Film for Mobile Devices
subject: FILM

description: An examination of the key events and ideas that shape the modern motion picture business from financial, institutional, and historical standpoints. Topics include ways that the business has evolved in response to changes in technology, distribution, and competition; how the business dictates what ends up on screen; and relationships among studios, actors, agents, independent filmmakers, distributors, and the viewing audience. Industry practitioners discuss special topics. 1 Credit. Tuition $3,300. Session B: July 8 - August 9.
title: Money and Media: The Business of Hollywood
subject: FILM

description: This course will examine the representation of American history on film and digital video, through the close analysis of American films from the beginning of the twentieth century to today. Topics will include: the Jazz Age, the Great Depression, World War II, the 1960s, Watergate, the Reagan Era, and post-9/11. Emphasis will be placed on the ways that films represent the historical moment from which they come. This course seeks to expand students' knowledge of the history of American film, culture, and society. Class screenings will feature such films as The Jazz Singer, It Happened One Night, The Best Years of Our Lives, Easy Rider, E.T., Do the Right Thing, and Traffic. 1 Credit. Tuition $3,300. Session B: July 8 - August 9.
title: Film, Video, and American History
subject: FILM

description: An exploration of the Himalayan region through film and ethnography. Visual and textual genres of storytelling and narration are used to examine topics such as adventure, caste, education, gender, ritual, and violence. Films and readings are drawn from Bhutan, northern India, Nepal, and Tibet. 1 Credit. Tuition $3,300. Session A: June 3 - July 5.
title: Himalaya through Film and Text
subject: FILM

description: The intersection of global health and visual media. Focus on international issues such as HIV, TB, human rights, and armed conflict. Film as a means for translating complex public health concepts into a format approachable by a general audience. Recommended preparation: a course in public health. 1 Credit. Tuition $3,300. Session A: June 3 - July 5.
title: Visual Approaches to Global Health
subject: FILM

description: A seminar and workshop in screenplay writing. Students learn the basics of the craft by reading existing scripts, looking at films from a writer's perspective, and writing a short screenplay. Additional hours of individual screenings required. Enrollment limited to 15. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,300. Session A: June 3 - July 5.
title: Screenwriting
subject: FILM

description: The outlaw as a romanticized, mythical figure in Anglo-American film and culture. Analysis of movies and screenplays whose characters refuse to conform to a restrictive social order in which they have a marginal place. Evolving depictions of the outlaw in mainstream cinema after World War II. 1 Credit. Tuition $3,300. Session B: July 8 -ÂAugust 9.
title: Outlaw Cinema
subject: FILM

description: Examines crime dramas, reality television, news coverage, and crime documentaries. Analysis of how popular media shapes public views on criminality, law enforcement, violence, due process, and judicial responsibility. Pays attention to the historical relationship between media, crime, and the politics of race, class, gender, and sexuality. 1 Credit. Tuition $3,300. Session A: June 3 - July 5.
title: Television and Crime
subject: FILM

description: An introductory analysis of the television situation comedy in America from its beginnings in the 1950s to the present time. Exploration of how this popular and powerful genre grew and changed; how it influenced America; and how it was influenced by America in its depictions of family life, race and ethnicity, stereotypes, fantasy, feminism, war, progressive forms of cultural and racial inclusion, and contemporary looks at single life and gay liberation. 1 Credit. Tuition $3,300. Session B: July 8 - August 9.
title: Television Situation Comedy
subject: FILM

description: Five weeks in New Haven, five weeks in Paris. An intensive "at-home-and-abroad" course designed for students with no previous study of French. This course focuses on developing all language skills, communicative proficiency, self-expression, and cultural insights through extensive use of authentic audio, video material, and field trips. Conducted entirely in unsimplified French. Daily classroom attendance, language laboratory work, and all field trips are required. Priority is given to Yale students. Students are responsible for all travel expenses to and from Paris, costs of room and board in Paris, and all other expenses beyond tuition. Application deadline: March 1. Must be taken in conjunction with FREN S120. Enrollment limited. For further information visit the Yale Summer Session website. 1 1/2 credits. Tuition: $3,300. Course dates: June 3 - August 10.
title: Elementary and Intermediate French I
subject: FREN

Conducted entirely in unsimplified French. Daily classroom attendance, language laboratory work, and all field trips are required. Priority is given to Yale students. subject: FREN

description: Four weeks in New Haven, four weeks in Paris. An intensive "at-home-and-abroad" course designed to perfect students' skills in understanding spoken and written French and in speaking and writing. subject: FREN

description: Offered in Paris, France. An advanced language course intended to improve students' comprehension of spoken and written French as well as their speaking and writing skills. Excursions to museums, movies, and theaters complement the reading of modern fiction and nonfiction texts. Students are responsible for all travel expenses to and from Paris, costs of room and board, and all other expenses beyond tuition. Application deadline: March 1. Prerequisite: after FREN 140, 145, or equivalent. Enrollment limited. For further information visit the Yale Summer Session website. 1 Credit. Tuition $3,300. Course dates: June 1 - July 6.
title: Advanced Language Practice II
subject: FREN

description: Offered in Paris, France. Intensive oral practice for advanced students. An introduction to contemporary French culture and current events while sharing day-to-day life with Parisians. In small groups, students conduct surveys and interviews, melding the techniques of ethnography and photojournalism. Classroom activities include students' presentation of their findings, discussions and debates based on readings of newspapers and other periodicals, films, songs, stories, and clips from French television. Students are responsible for all travel expenses to and from Paris, costs of room and board in Paris, and all other expenses beyond tuition. Application deadline: March 1. Prerequisite: after FREN 150, 151, or equivalent proficiency. Enrollment limited. For further information visit the Yale Summer Session website. 1 Credit. Tuition $3,300. Course dates: June 1 - July 6.
title: Advanced Culture and Conversation
subject: FREN

description: Offered in Paris, France. Conducted in English. A study of the culture and monuments of the High Middle Ages in France, with visits to Notre-Dame de Paris, Saint Denis, Chartres, Sainte-Chapelle, Amiens, Beauvais, Rouen, Cluny Museum, and discussion of accompanying historical, literary, and philosophical works by Abelard, Suger, Rutebeuf, Saint Bernard, Joinville, Thibault de Champagne, Pseudo-Dionysius, Marie de France, Jacques de Voragine, Guibert de Nogent, and the anonymous Song of Roland, Quest for the Holy Grail, fabliaux, and courtly lyric. Core consideration of Gothic architecture, urban and economic renewal, and intellectual and religious life of  twelfth-  and thirteenth-century France. Students choose HUMS, LITR, or FREN credit. Students are responsible for all travel expenses to and from Paris, costs of room and board, and all other expenses beyond tuition. Application deadline: March 1. Enrollment limited. For further information visit the Yale Summer Session website. 2 Credits. Tuition $6,400. Course dates: July 6 - August 10.
title: Age of Cathedrals
subject: FREN

description: Offered in Paris, France. A study of important works of literature, painting, sculpture, architecture, music, and the decorative arts in turn-of-the-century France (1870-1914). This course will acquaint students with the principal literary and artistic forms, social trends, political movements, scientific theories, and technological innovations of the Belle Epoque, with visits to museums, architectural monuments, theater, and art nouveau cafes in Paris. Principal authors: Zola, Gide, Proust, Bergson, Apollinaire, Maupassant, Mallarme, Colette, Alain-Fournier, Barbey d'Aurevilly, Simmel, Jarry, and Feydeau. Students choose HUMS, LITR, or FREN credit. Conducted in English. Students are responsible for all travel expenses to and from Paris, costs of room and board, and all other expenses beyond tuition. Application deadline: March 1. Enrollment limited. For further information visit the Yale Summer Session website. 2 Credits. Tuition $6,400. Course dates: June 1 - July 6
title: Belle Epoque France
subject: FREN

description: Offered online. Methods used in the social sciences to make inferences about causality and to explain causal relations, including experiments, quantitative and qualitative methods, case studies, and fieldwork. Defining causation; methods for causal attribution; strengths and limitations of real-world research designs; practicalities and logistics of doing research; conceptualization and measurement. Enrollment limited. For college students only. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,300. Technology fee: $85. Session A: June 3 - July 5.
short_title: Cause and Effect in Social Sc...
title: Cause and Effect in Social Science Research
subject: GLBL

description: The mutual influence of law and politics at the international level. Topics include the sources of international law, the participants, courts, dispute settlement, jurisdiction, and customary law. Readings on foreign policy making, international law, treaties, and international courts from the literature of United Nations bodies and the International Law Commission. 1 Credit. Tuition $3,300. Session B: July 8 - August 9.
title: Foreign Policy and International Law
subject: GLBL

description: Introduction to the international human rights regime. Analysis of tools used by actors to promote human rights in the international system. Origins of the regime and contested notions of human rights. Issues include genocide, torture, and the rights of women, children, and sexual minorities. 1 Credit. Tuition $3,300. Session A: June 3 - July 5.
title: Introduction to Human Rights Theory and Practice
subject: GLBL

description: Offered in Ifrane and Rabat, Morocco. The Maghrib--Morocco, Algeria, Tunisia, and Libya--has historically been a critical frontier zone linking Africa, the Middle East, and Europe. This crossroads remains strategically important with sub-Saharan and North African migration, political Islam, Arab-Berber identity, terrorism and counterterrorism, the Sahara question, and Mediterranean trade relationships being current international concerns. This course provides a thorough overview of North African history, the legacies of colonialism and nationalism, political systems and opposition, Islam in North Africa, and the Maghrib in the twenty-first century. Students will meet with local experts, interact with Moroccan university students, and be able to do optional home stays with Moroccan families. Students are responsible for all travel expenses to and from Morocco, room and board costs in Morocco, and any other expenses beyond tuition. Application deadline: March 1. Enrollment limited. For further information visit the Yale Summer Session website. 2 Credits. Tuition $6,400. Course dates: June 1 - July 6.
title: Society and Politics of North Africa
subject: GLBL

description: Four weeks in New Haven, four weeks in Berlin. An intensive, content-based language course that teaches linguistic skills through a variety of literary and nonfiction texts and film, with special emphasis on the culture and history of Berlin. Students are responsible for all travel expenses to and from Berlin, costs of room and board, and all other expenses beyond tuition. Application deadline: March 1. Enrollment limited. Must be taken in conjunction with GMAN S140. Prerequisite: GMAN 120 or equivalent. For further information visit the Yale Summer Session website. 1 1/2 Credits. Tuition $3,300. Course dates: June 3 - July 27.

title: Beginning Greek: The Elements of Greek Grammar
subject: GREK

title: Beginning Greek: Review of Grammar and Selected Readings
subject: GREK

description: Introduction to the study and writing of history, focusing on how African Americans fought for civil rights throughout the twentieth century. The civil rights movement placed in its historical context; African American freedom struggles placed in the larger narrative of U.S. history. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,300. Session A: June 3 - July 5.
title: The Civil Rights Movement
subject: HIST

description: The history of westward expansion and of the places west of the Mississippi River, as told through the people who saw it, experienced it, and made it happen. Beginning in the colonial era and concluding in the present day, with an emphasis on the nineteenth and twentieth centuries and international comparisons. Research will include the use of materials held at the Beinecke. 1 Credit. Tuition $3,300. Session A: June 3 - July 5.
title: History of the American West
subject: HIST

description: The history of slavery from the seventeenth-century development of racial slavery in the Americas through contemporary forms of enslavement and human trafficking. Theories on the origins of slavery; definitions of slavery; the slave societies of the Caribbean and North America; the transatlantic slave trade; nineteenth-century abolitionism and emancipations; and the persistence of slavery in the twentieth century. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,300. Session B: July 8 - August 9.
title: History of American Slavery
subject: HIST

description: Scientific and medical ideas about the natural world and the body have long been influenced by concepts of gender, even as expectations regarding gender have been shaped by scientific theories. Students will explore the historical relationship between gender and science, medicine, and technology in Western society, from the medieval and early modern period through to contemporary American debates. Students will analyze the relationship between science, medicine, and gender in order to gain historical insights and a critical perspective with regard to the structure of scientific and medical practice. Class visits to the Medical Historical Library and Peabody Museum expected. 1 Credit. Tuition $3,300. Session A: June 3 - July 5.
title: Gender in Science and Medicine
subject: HIST

Emphasis will be placed on the ways that films represent the historical moment from which they come. This course seeks to expand students' knowledge of the history of American film, culture, and society. Session B: July 8 - August 9.

subject: HIST

This crossroads remains strategically important, with sub-Saharan and North African migration, political Islam, Arab-Berber identity, terrorism and counter-terrorism, the Sahara question, and Mediterranean trade relationships being current international concerns. description: Survey of the political, social, economic, and cultural history of Europe since the sixteenth century. Special attention to theories and debates about the rise of the West. Agricultural, commercial, and industrial development; demographic change and social stratification; mass migration, trade, and globalization; religion and political ideology; monarchies, republics, and empires; revolutions, wars, and international orders; elite and popular cultures. 1 Credit. Tuition $3,300. Session A: June 3 - July 5.
title: The Western World since 1500
subject: HIST

description: Examines the Cold War as a struggle for ideological and geopolitical preeminence, tracing its origins, stagnation, and unexpected end from the perspectives of three worlds: capitalist, socialist, and postcolonial. Sources include declassified documents, contemporary fiction and recent secondary reinterpretations, films, and field trips. 1 Credit. Tuition $3,300. Session B: July 8 - August 9.
title: The Cold War
subject: HIST

description: The destruction of European Jewry explored within the context of twentieth-century German and East European history. Conditions that led up to the Holocaust; regional variations of its perpetration. Contemporary interpretations of the Holocaust, including reasons they remain controversial. 1 Credit. Tuition $3,300. Session A: June 3 - July 5.
title: Holocaust in Historical Perspective
subject: HIST

description: Offered in Dubrovnik, Croatia. Multidisciplinary study from antiquity to modernity. Byzantine presence and the remnants of the Roman world; consequences of the schism between Rome and Constantinople; barbarian kingdoms and the medieval city-states; Ottoman incursions and millets; Renaissance and Baroque; beginning of nationalism and modern national integrations; national revolutions, fascism, communism, and postcommunist conflicts; secularization of religion; genocide in post-Yugoslav wars. Students are responsible for all travel expenses to and from Dubrovnik, room and board costs in Croatia, and any other expenses beyond tuition. Must be taken in conjunction with SOCY S286. Application deadline: March 1. Enrollment limited. For further information visit the Yale Summer Session website. 1 Credit. Tuition $3,200. Course dates: June 30 - August 3.
title: History and Culture of Southeastern Europe
subject: HIST

description: A survey of Japan's transformation over the course of the nineteenth century from an isolated, traditional society on the edge of northeast Asia to a modern imperial power. Aspects of political, social, and cultural history. 1 Credit. Tuition $3,300. Session A: June 3 - July 5.
title: Japan's Modern Revolution
subject: HIST

description: Survey of the history of China, Japan, and Korea from the seventh century to the present. Focus on two separate empires: the Tang and Japanese. Attention to interactions among East Asian regions in the past and today. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,300. Session B: July 8 - August 9.
title: Empires of East Asia
subject: HIST

Field trips to Yale museums and architectural walking tours complement the study of paintings, sculptures, architecture, and domestic and luxury arts. Readings include survey texts and original sources. 1 Credit. Tuition $3,300. Session B: July 8 - August 9.
title: Introduction to the History of Art: Renaissance tothe Present
subject: HSAR

description: Interacting with and writing about popular culture from an art-historical perspective. Focus on the intersections of art, music, and digital media design. Discussion of networks, virality, repetition, and memes, including their implications on a global stage. Case studies from music videos, smartphone and tablet apps, websites, and digital operating systems. 1 Credit. Tuition $3,300. Session A: June 3 - July 5.
title: Critical Approaches to Contemporary Media
subject: HSAR

description: The historical relationship between art and science in the West, from the Renaissance to the present. Case studies illustrate the similarities and differences between the way artists and scientists each model the world, in the studio and the laboratory. 1 Credit. Tuition $3,300. Session A: June 3 - July 5.
title: Art and Science
subject: HSAR

description: In-depth discussion of ten major works of Western art from the Renaissance to the modern era. Works selected both for their extraordinary qualities and for their capacity to represent a range of periods, places, media, themes, and functions. Includes visits to Yale's art museums to view corollary works of art; some attention to relevant poetry, literature, and film. 1 Credit. Tuition $3,300. Session B: July 8 - August 9.
title: Ten Works of Western Art
subject: HSAR

description: Exploration of the contemporary Hollywood film industry. Introduction to the close analysis of film sequences. Central components of a Hollywood production, such as script, director, star, and genre. Aspects of the industry, including production, distribution, and exhibition. Ingredients of blockbuster success; why some films fail catastrophically. Case studies pair current films with historical ones. Includes two screenings per week. 1 Credit. Tuition $3,300. Session A: June 3 - July 5.
title: The Blockbuster and the Bomb
subject: HSAR

Students will analyze the relationship between science, medicine, and gender in order to gain historical insights and a critical perspective with regard to the structure of scientific and medical practice. description: A study of the myths of Greek and Roman gods and heroes. The literary forms, historical contexts, and cultural uses of classical mythologies. Subsequent development and reception of these myths in various cultures and media from the Renaissance to the present. Analyses of these myths over the course of the past two centuries. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,300. Session A: June 3 - July 5.
title: Classical Mythologies
subject: HUMS

description: Introduction to the construction and performance of heroism in Greek tragic drama, with close reading of selected plays in translation. Focus on the sagas of the House of Atreus and Oedipus. Defining the tragic hero; the tragic flaw; characterization and stagecraft; playwrights' responses to the Homeric hero; modern responses to Greek tragedy. Includes screenings of film adaptations of the plays. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,300. Session A: June 3 - July 5.
