title: The Tragic Hero in Greek Drama
subject: HUMS

description: Representations of the human body in law and literature. The complex nature of how humans think about and give meaning to their bodies in relationship to themselves and to others. 1 Credit. Tuition $3,300. Session A: June 3 - July 5.
title: Bodies in Law and Literature
subject: HUMS

description: Offered in Siena, Italy. This five-week course combines beginning Italian with a course in English on Italian cinema focusing on Tuscany. Students will learn Italian through classes and full-immersion in the study-abroad experience (including a homestay), and will explore the representation of Tuscany through the screening and close analysis of films where the Tuscan setting has been elevated to the level of a primary thematic concern. Among the films to be considered are Room with a View, Night of the Shooting Stars, The First Beautiful Thing, Tea with Mussolini, The Sky Is Falling, Life Is Beautiful, Sandra, Mar nero, Good Morning Babylon, Fiorile, and the Florentine episode of Paisa. Students who wish to continue with Italian are required to take a placement test in order to place into ITAL 120. Students may petition for one HU credit. Students are responsible for all travel expenses to and from Siena, room and board costs in Italy, and any other expenses beyond tuition. Application deadline: March 1. Enrollment limited. For further information visit the Yale Summer Session website. 2 Credits. Tuition $6,400. Course dates: June 22 - July 27.
title: Italian Language and Cinema in Tuscany
subject: HUMS

description: Modernity's fascination with the myth of Dionysus. Questions of agency, identity and community, and psychological integrity and the modern constitution of the self. Manifestations of Dionysus in literature, anthropology, and music; the Apollonian-Dionysiac dichotomy; twentieth-century variations of these themes in psychoanalysis, surrealism, and magical realism. 1 Credit. Tuition $3,300. Session A: June 3 - July 5.
title: Dionysius in Modernity
subject: HUMS

description: Changes in the understanding of evil over the last century. Ways in which literature and film represent evil, assign a central role to it, and try to comprehend it, eliminate it, or lock it away as far and as long as possible. 1 Credit. Tuition $3,300. Session A: June 3 - July 5.
title: On Evil
subject: HUMS

description: The nature, history, and possible meanings of dream experience, with reference to Sigmund Freud's Interpretation of Dreams. Works from film and literature about dreams and dreaming, as well as major texts in dream theory. 1 Credit. Tuition $3,300. Session B: July 8 - August 9.
title: The Logic of Dreams
subject: HUMS

description: Offered in Rome, Italy. Designed as the logical complement and correlation to HUMS 444, this course will consider how Rome's contributions to Western thought are recorded in the very fabric of the city. Open to Yale students only. Students are responsible for all travel expenses to and from Rome, costs of room and board, and all other expenses beyond tuition. Application deadline: March 1. Prerequisite: HUMS 444. Enrollment limited, with preference to Humanities majors and juniors. For further information visit the Yale Summer Session website. 2 Credits. Tuition $6,400. Course dates: June 2 - July 6.
title: Rome
subject: HUMS

description: Offered in Auvillar, France. Open to both Yale and non-Yale students from liberal arts and fine arts backgrounds with or without prior experience. Studio Practice is an intensive study of painting and drawing focusing on the dynamics of the artist's studio practice of developing and constructing work. It is crafted for those who wish to study and experience the intimate process of personal idea imaging through the language of painting and drawing. Of great importance to the course is the development of strategies necessary for individual discovery, observation/analysis,and relational thinking. The residential program demands commitment, a strong work ethic and study within a 24/7 curriculum. All applicants should consult Robert Reed prior to completing the online application. Enrollment is limited to 15 participants. Students are responsible for all travel expenses to and from Auvillar, room and board costs in France, and any other expenses beyond tuition. Application deadline: March 1. Interview required. Enrollment limited. For further information visit the Yale Summer Session website. 2 Credits. Tuition $6,400. Course dates: June 1 - June 29.

description: Offered in Paris, France. Conducted in English. A study of the culture and monuments of the High Middle Ages in France, with visits to Notre-Dame de Paris, Saint Denis, Chartres, Sainte-Chapelle, Amiens, Beauvais, Rouen, Cluny Museum, and discussion of accompanying historical, literary, and philosophical works by Abelard, Suger, Rutebeuf, Saint Bernard, Joinville, Thibault de Champagne, Pseudo-Dionysius, Marie de France, Jacques de Voragine, Guibert de Nogent, and the anonymous Song of Roland, Quest for the Holy Grail, fabliaux, and courtly lyric. Core consideration of Gothic architecture, urban and economic renewal, and intellectual and religious life of  twelfth and thirteenth-century France. Students choose HUMS, LITR, or FREN credit. Students are responsible for all travel expenses to and from Paris, costs of room and board, and all other expenses beyond tuition. Application deadline: March 1. Enrollment limited. For further information visit the Yale Summer Session website. 2 Credits. Tuition $6,400. Course dates: July 6 - August 10.

description: Must be taken in New Haven. May be arranged for currently enrolled Yale students in Ecology and Evolutionary Biology; Engineering and Applied Science; Geology and Geophysics; Chemistry; Molecular Biophysics and Biochemistry; Molecular, Cellular, and Developmental Biology; Physics; or any other science department sponsoring such programs. These programs are especially useful for juniors in providing them with actual research experience prior to application to graduate or professional schools. Students wishing to enroll must complete the regular application for Yale Summer Session. In addition, students must submit written permission of (1) the faculty sponsor, who should also supply a one- or two-paragraph description of the research to be undertaken including the proposed starting and ending dates, (2) the Director of Summer Sciences, and (3) the director of undergraduate studies of the applicant's major department Students taking Independent Research for 1 credit must work 35 hours a week for five weeks (either Session A or B); for 2 credits students must work 35 hours a week for ten weeks (both Session A and B). Students may receive academic credit only if they are not being paid for doing research, but they may work for credit in one 5-week period and for pay in the other. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,300. Session A: June 3 - July 5.

description: Offered in Siena, Italy. This five-week course combines beginning Italian with a course in English on Italian cinema focusing on Tuscany. Students will learn Italian through classes and full-immersion in the study-abroad experience (including a homestay), and will explore the representation of Tuscany through the screening and close analysis of films where the Tuscan setting has been elevated to the level of a primary thematic concern. Among the films to be considered are Room with a View, Night of the Shooting Stars, The First Beautiful Thing, Tea with Mussolini, The Sky Is Falling, Life Is Beautiful, Sandra, Mar nero, Good Morning Babylon, Fiorile, and the Florentine episode of Paisa. Students who wish to continue with Italian are required to take a placement test in order to place into ITAL 120. Students may petition for one HU credit. Students are responsible for all travel expenses to and from Siena, room and board costs in Italy, and any other expenses beyond tuition. Application deadline: March 1. Enrollment limited. description: Offered in Siena, Italy. The course will focus on close readings of a selection of short stories (novella) from the Decameron, the masterpiece of Giovanni Boccaccio. It will define the context of Boccaccio's narrative, placing it first of all in the cultural geography of Tuscany (Siena, Florence, Certaldo, his native town). Secondly, the discussion will explore Boccaccio's specific intellectual framework: the sense of nature; the place of human beings in the natural world; the value of medicine in the face of the Plague; the economy of the marketplace; the bourgeois ethos of selfishness, politics, tyranny, and power within the household (such as authority in the family, the place of women, sexuality). Using his native Tuscan vernacular, Boccaccio shaped his short stories and their frame to reveal the relationship between human passions, imagination, and literature. Taught entirely in Italian. Open to both Yale and non-Yale students. Prerequisite: ITAL 140, 145, or equivalent. Students are responsible for all travel expenses to and from Siena, room and board costs in Italy, and any other expenses beyond tuition. Application deadline: March 1. Enrollment limited. For further information visit the Yale Summer Session website. 1 Credit. Tuition $3,300. Course dates: June 22 - July 27.
title: Culture, Language, and Passions in Boccaccio's Decameron
subject: ITAL

description: Responses of Latin American thinkers to fundamental questions in social and political philosophy, from colonial times to the twentieth century. title: Beginning Latin: Review of Grammar and Selected Readings

description: A study of the myths of Greek and Roman gods and heroes. The literary forms, historical contexts, and cultural uses of classical mythologies. Subsequent development and reception of these myths in various cultures and media from the Renaissance to the present. Analyses of these myths over the course of the past two centuries. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,300. Session A: June 3 - July 5.

A study of the culture and monuments of the High Middle Ages in France, with visits to Notre-Dame de Paris, Saint Denis, Chartres, Sainte-Chapelle, Amiens, Beauvais, Rouen, Cluny Museum,  and discussion of accompanying historical, literary, and philosophical works by Abelard, Suger, Rutebeuf, Saint Bernard, Joinville, Thibault de Champagne, Pseudo-Dionysius, Marie de France, Jacques de Voragine, Guibert de Nogent, and the anonymous Song of Roland, Quest for the Holy Grail, fabliaux, and courtly lyric. description: Modernity's fascination with the myth of Dionysus. Questions of agency, identity and community, and psychological integrity and the modern constitution of the self. Manifestations of Dionysus in literature, anthropology, and music; the Apollonian-Dionysiac dichotomy; twentieth-century variations of these themes in psychoanalysis, surrealism, and magical realism. 1 Credit. Tuition $3,300. Session A: June 3 - July 5.
title: Dionysus in Modernity
subject: LITR

description: Offered in Paris, France. A study of important works of literature, painting, sculpture, architecture, music, and the decorative arts in turn-of-the-century France (1870-1914). This course will acquaint students with the principal literary and artistic forms, social trends, political movements, scientific theories, and technological innovations of the Belle Epoque, with visits to museums, architectural monuments, theater, and art nouveau cafes in Paris.  Principal authors: Zola, Gide, Proust, Bergson, Apollinaire, Maupassant, Mallarme, Colette, Alain-Fournier, Barbey d'Aurevilly, Simmel, Jarry, and Feydeau. Students choose HUMS, LITR, or FREN credit. Conducted in English. Students are responsible for all travel expenses to and from Paris, costs of room and board, and all other expenses beyond tuition. Application deadline: March 1. Enrollment limited. For further information visit the Yale Summer Session website. 2 Credits. Tuition $6,400. Course dates: June 1 - July 6
title: Belle Epoque France
subject: LITR

description: The nature, history, and possible meanings of dream experience, with reference to Sigmund Freud'sÂ Interpretation of Dreams. Works from film and literature about dreams and dreaming, as well as major texts in dream theory. 1 Credit. Tuition $3,300. Session B: July 8 - August 9.
title: The Logic of Dreams
subject: LITR

description: Changes in the understanding of evil over the last century. Ways in which literature and film represent evil, assign a central role to it, and try to comprehend it, eliminate it, or lock it away as far and as long as possible. 1 Credit. Tuition $3,300. Session A: June 3 - July 5.
title: On Evil
subject: LITR

description: Survey of early twentieth-century German and Russian literature, philosophy, and visual arts. Focus on science fiction and visions of the future, including texts and images that depict Martians, evil robots, and the undead. Artistic audacity, uncertainty, and experimentation that dominated both avant-garde and mass cultures of the period. Readings and discussion in English. Click here for a video trailer for the course. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,300. Session B: July 8 - August 9.

description: Global exploration of embodied ritual performance in Islam. Case studies range from ceremonies of the Mevlevi dervishes in Turkey to activist art in the context of U.S. detention and deportation of Muslims after 9/11. Development of practical skills in ethnographic research. 1 Credit. Tuition $3,300. Session A: June 3 - July 5.

description: Offered in Ifrane and Rabat, Morocco. The Maghrib--Morocco, Algeria, Tunisia, and Libya--has historically been a critical frontier zone linking Africa, the Middle East, and Europe. This crossroads remains strategically important with sub-Saharan and North African migration, political Islam, Arab-Berber identity, terrorism and counterterrorism, the Sahara question, and Mediterranean trade relationships being current international concerns. This course provides a thorough overview of North African history, the legacies of colonialism and nationalism, political systems and opposition, Islam in North Africa, and the Maghrib in the twenty-first century. Students will meet with local experts, interact with Moroccan university students, and be able to do optional home stays with Moroccan families. Students are responsible for all travel expenses to and from Morocco, room and board costs in Morocco, and any other expenses beyond tuition. Application deadline: March 1. Enrollment limited. For further information visit the Yale Summer Session website. 2 Credits. Tuition $6,400. Course dates: June 1 - July 6.
title: Society and Politics of North Africa
subject: MMES

description: The fundamentals of musical language (notation, rhythm, scales, keys, melodies, and chords), including writing, analysis, singing, and dictation. Intended for students who have no music reading ability. 1 Credit. Tuition $3,300. Session B: July 8 - August 9.

subject: MUSI

description: Offered online. Development of aural skills that lead to an understanding of Western music. The musical novice is introduced to the ways in which music is put together and is taught how to listen to a wide variety of musical styles, from Bach and Mozart, to Gregorian chant, to the blues. Enrollment limited. For college students only. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,300. Technology fee: $85. Session B: July 8 - August 9.

subject: MUSI

description: Offered online. A study of the evolution of jazz, from its precursors in the music of Africa through its beginnings in New Orleans to its fusion with rock in the 1970s. Jazz's greatest artists and their styles are presented with selected music of each jazz period and a discussion of the racial and sociological factors surrounding the genre's development. While no extensive music theory background or formal instrumental experience is required, students who can read music will be best prepared to fulfill the listening and form identification assignments. Enrollment limited. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,300. Technology fee: $85. Session A: June 3 - July 5.
title: Jazz and Race in America
subject: MUSI

description: An intensive immersion course designed to familiarize students with modern and colonial Nahuatl. Beginning, intermediate, and advanced level students may apply. description: Historical and analytical inquiry into the meanings of happiness and their change over time. How new approaches to this topic in the social and natural sciences both complement and challenge time-honored philosophical and religious ideas. Whether happiness is a subjective and/or culturally relative idea; whether happiness should be a goal in life. The relationship of happiness to other valued goods such as meaning, freedom, pleasure, virtue, and justice. 1 Credit. Tuition $3,300. Session A: June 3 - July 5.
title: Happiness
subject: PHIL

description: Introduction to the history and methods of philosophical reflection and inquiry. Exploration of several perennial philosophical issues and the distinctive ways of addressing these issues through a close reading of historical texts and group discussion. Readings include selections from the works of Plato, Aristotle, Hume, Kant, Mill, and twentieth-century philosophers. 1 Credit. Tuition $3,300. Session B: July 8 - August 9.
title: Introduction to Philosophy
subject: PHIL

description: An introduction to the philosophy of religion, focusing on the problem of evil: if there is an all-powerful and morally good God, then why is there so much evil in the world? Examination of attempts to reconcile the existence of God with evil by appealing to human free will. Such attempts raise other important philosophical questions: what is free will, and is it compatible with the laws of physics, or with divine providence? Why is freedom valuable? 1 Credit. Tuition $3,300. Session A: June 3 - July 5.
title: Free Will, God, and Evil
subject: PHIL

description: An introduction to formal logic. Study of the formal deductive systems and semantics for both propositional and predicate logic. Some discussion of metatheory. 1 Credit. Tuition $3,300. Session B: July 8 - August 9.
title: First-Order Logic
subject: PHIL

description: Offered online. The modern science of moral thought and moral action explored through disciplines such as cognitive science, social and developmental psychology, neuroscience, behavioral economics, and analytic philosophy. Empathy and compassion in babies and young children; emotional reactions to family, friends, and strangers; the origins of prejudice and bigotry; sexuality, disgust, and purity; punishment, revenge, and forgiveness; the relationship between morality and religion. For college students only. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3300. Technology fee: $85. Session B: July 8 - August 9.
title: Moralities of Everyday Life
subject: PHIL

description: Overview of central ethical questions within the global arena. Topics include international governance, just war, human rights, genocide, global justice, humanitarian intervention, and economic sanctions. 1 Credit. Tuition $3,300. Session A: June 3 - July 5.
title: International Ethics
subject: PHIL

description: Introduction to Eastern philosophy through the study of philosophical and religious texts. Topics include reality and illusion, knowledge, self, right and wrong, nonattachment, meditation, aesthetics, the meaning of life, and death. 1 Credit. Tuition $3,300. Session B: July 8 - August 9.
title: Eastern Philosophy
subject: PHIL

description: Questions about human responsibilities for the environment. Wilderness protection, sustainability, preservation of species, the costs of fighting global warming, and humans' right to a healthy environment. Attention to analytical and argumentative skills required in legal and environmental advocacy. 1 Credit. Tuition $3,300. Session B: July 8 - August 9.
title: Environmental Ethics
subject: PHIL

description: Introduction to contemporary philosophical debate about the nature of lies and deception. Definitions of lying and deception, including whether all lies necessarily aim to deceive; moral justifications for lying and deceit and their counterarguments; ways in which the moral arguments against deception of others can apply to self-deception. Recommended preparation: EP&E 215 or a course in political philosophy. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,300. Session A: June 3 - July 5.
title: Lies and Deception
subject: PHIL

description: Seminar that examines the science behind selected advances in modern technology. Focus on the scientific and contextual basis of each advance, as well as the technology's resulting impact on society. Student groups present case studies, with topics developed by the participants in collaboration with the instructor. Intended for nonÃ¢ÂÂscience majors. Enrollment limited. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,300. Session A: June 3 - July 5.
title: Science of Modern Technology
subject: PHYS

description: Seminar that covers the technology, use, and impact of energy on the environment, climate, security, and the economy. Emphasis on what drives people's choices and the effects of those choices. Prerequisite: a strong background in high school physics, chemistry, and mathematics. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,300. Session B: July 8 - August 9.
title: Energy, Technology and Society
subject: PHYS

Emphasis on fundamental principles and on applications drawn from the life sciences and medicine. Covers vectors, kinematics, Newtonâs laws of motion, oscillations and waves, gravitation, elasticity, statics, diffusion, fluids, and thermodynamics. Suitable for students interested in the biological and medical sciences. Intended primarily for college students. Precollege students with a background in physics and a solid basis in calculus may apply subject to instructor's approval. PHYS 150 and 151 are normally taken in sequence. 1 Credit. Tuition $3,300. Session A: June 3 - July 5.

subject: PHYS

Suitable for students interested in the biological and medical sciences. Intended primarily for college students. description: Issues of liberty, equality, and justice considered from within the Western tradition of political philocophy. Readings from Plato, Aristotle, Hobbes, Locke, Rousseau, Marx, Mill and contemporary authors. 1 Credit. Tuition $3,300. Session B: July 8 - August 9.

description: Introduction to the international human rights regime. Analysis of tools used by actors to promote human rights in the international system. Origins of the regime and contested notions of human rights. Issues include genocide, torture, and the rights of women, children, and sexual minorities. 1 Credit. Tuition $3,300. description: The mutual influence of law and politics at the international level. Topics include the sources of international law, the participants, courts, dispute settlement, jurisdiction, and customary law. subject: PLSC

description: American grand strategy since the collapse of the Soviet Union. The ability of the United States to project its power around the world. Constraints on and challenges to American power in the international political system. The effect of nuclear weapons on the workings of a unipolar world. The possible emergence of peer competitors in the future. 1 Credit. Tuition $3,300. Session B: July 8 - August 9.

title: U.S. Strategy After the Cold War

subject: PLSC

description: Examines the Cold War as a struggle for ideological and geopolitical preeminence, tracing its origins, stagnation, and unexpected end from the perspectives of three worlds: capitalist, socialist, and postcolonial. Sources include declassified documents, contemporary fiction and recent secondary reinterpretations, films, and field trips. 1 Credit. Tuition $3,300. Session B: July 8 - August 9.

subject: PLSC

subject: PLSC

Tuition $3,300. Session A: June 3 - July 5.

description: Study of contemporary work on ethnicity and nationalism from multiple disciplines and analytic traditions. Factors that make ethnicity and nationalism distinctive among social bases of political mobilization. Critical examination of the theory that nationalism is an exclusively modern phenomenon. Nationalism as an attempt to tie powerful organizations to specific territories and individual loyalties. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,300. Session A: June 3 - July 5.

How the fields of philosophy, psychology, neuroscience, computer science, and linguistics contribute methods, theories, and research to addressing questions about how the mind works. 1 Credit. description: Introduction to theories of human emotion from diverse fields in psychology. How emotions are perceived, generated, and experienced; culture and gender differences; emotional development over the life span and across species; emotions in social relationships; emotion regulation, including dysregulation in mental illnesses. Prerequisite: PSYC 110 or equivalent. 1 Credit. Tuition $3,300. Session B: July 8 - August 9.

description: Offered online. Introduction to major discoveries and theories of human emotion. Evolutionary theories of the origins of emotion; culture, sex, and gender influences; emotion and morality; brain basis of emotion; sleeping and feeling; relationship between emotion and thinking; love and relationships; development of emotion; animal vs. human emotion; abnormal emotions in mental illness; and happiness. Prerequisite: PSYC 110 or equivalent. For college students only. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,300. Technology fee: $85. Session A: June 3 - July 5.

Empathy and compassion in babies and young children; emotional reactions to family, friends, and strangers; the origins of prejudice and bigotry; sexuality, disgust, and purity; punishment, revenge, and forgiveness; the relationship between morality and religion. For college students only. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,300. Technology fee: $85. Session B: July 8 - August 9.

Debates regarding religious violence, secularism, and atheism are also covered. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,300. Session A: June 3 - July 5.

description: Three weeks in New Haven, five weeks in St. Petersburg. This course explores the cultural history of the imperial Russian capital, founded by Peter the Great in the early eighteenth century as a window on Europe. Since then, the city has been seen to embody all of the contradictions of Russia: East vs. West, imperial grandeur vs. the pathos of the little man, nature vs. civilization, free will vs. fate. The course considers the semiotics of Petersburg through a careful reading of selected literary texts, both prose and poetry, including Pushkin, Gogol, Dostoevsky, Blok, Bely, Gumilev, Akhmatova, Mandelstam, Khlebnikov, Mayakovsky, Kharms, and others, as well as some works of literary and cultural criticism. The classroom sessions are complemented with a rich selection of excursions and tours in and around St.Petersburg. Students are responsible for all travel expenses to and from St. Petersburg, costs of room and board, and any other expenses beyond tuition. Application deadline: March 1. Enrollment limited. Must be taken in conjunction with either RUSS 130/140 or RUSS S150/151. For further information visit the Yale Summer Session website. 1 Credit. Tuition: see RUSS S130/140 or RUSS S 150/151.  Course Dates: June 3 - July 29.
title: Russian Culture
subject: RUSS

description: Offered in Mumbai, India. Students will have the opportunity to study and be in class with local students from St. Xavier's University. Critical engagement with contemporary Indian politics, society, culture and religion through an intensive and immersive study in Mumbai, one of the largest cities in the world. Topics include: urban poverty, urban town planning, housing problems, sanitation, cultural politics, religious and sectarian violence, caste politics, class ghettoization, communal violence, migration, urbanârural divide, Bollywood and popular culture. Students are responsible for all travel expenses to and from India, costs of room and board, and all other expenses beyond tuition. Application deadline: March 1. Enrollment limited. For further information visit the Yale Summer Session website. 2 Credits. Tuition $6,400. Course dates: June 1 - July 5.

Visual and textual genres of storytelling and narration are used to examine topics such as adventure, caste, education, gender, ritual, and violence. Films and readings are drawn from Bhutan, northern India, Nepal, and Tibet. 1 Credit. Tuition $3,300. Session A: June 3 - July 5.
title: Himalaya through Film and Text

description: This course is intended to provide comprehensive training and support to STARS students engaged in scientific research. Students will be introduced to the scientific process, including hypothesis testing, experimental design, and data interpretation, through lectures, readings, and discussions of the primary scientific literature. Skills development will emphasize the process of discussions for preparing written scientific reports and oral presentations, highlighting effectual communication skills and the ability to interpret and display quantitative and qualitative information. For STARS students only. Course may not be repeated for credit. 1 credit. Tuition $3,300. June 9 - August 9.

Topics include the relationship between sex and gender; sex/gender difference and competing explanations for sexual inequality; gender and work; sex and sexuality in society; masculinity, gender, and sports; and feminism. 1 Credit. Tuition $3,300. Session A: June 3 - July 5.

subject: SOCY

description: An introduction to sociological approaches to crime and deviance. Review of patterns of illegal activity within society, data sources, and theoretical explanations. Topics include drug use, violence, and white-collar crime. 1 Credit. Tuition $3,300. Session B: July 8 - August 9.

subject: SOCY

description: Major works of social thought that articulate the core ideas of sociology. Attention to social and historical contexts, conceptual frameworks and methods, and contributions to contemporary social analysis. Writers include Hobbes, Locke, J.S. Mill, Rousseau, Marx, Durkheim, and Weber. 1 Credit. Tuition $3,300. Session A: June 3 - July 5.

subject: SOCY

description: Introduction to public health issues and health development processes that are independent of national territorial boundaries but also incorporate the health needs and priorities of individual nation-states. Mechanisms and challenges involved in incorporating the World Health Organization's commitment to primary health care with principles that currently dominate the global public health agenda. Sociological critique of public health interventions. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,300. Session B: July 8 - August 9.

subject: SOCY

description: Is there a link between social identity and crime?  What is the relationship among race, gender, and perceptions of criminality?  What has been the impact of increasing social diversity on forms of social control, crime, and criminal justice policy?  This seminar explores these questions by examining the intersection of multiculturalism, crime, and the criminal justice system.  Students will be introduced to major, relevant criminological and sociological concepts, theories, and debates. Class discussions will address contemporary social problems such as racial profiling, disproportionate punishment, mass incarceration, and unequal justice.  Examples draw principally from the American but also from the British context, providing a comparative perspective. 1 Credit. Tuition $3,300. Session A: June 3 - July 5.
title: Multiculturalism and the Ordered Society
subject: SOCY

description: Offered in Ifrane and Rabat, Morocco. The Maghrib--Morocco, Algeria, Tunisia, and Libya--has historically been a critical frontier zone linking Africa, the Middle East, and Europe.  This crossroads remains strategically important with sub-Saharan and North African migration, political Islam, Arab-Berber identity, terrorism and counter-terrorism, the Sahara question, and Mediterranean trade relationships current international concerns.  This course provides a thorough overview of North African history, the legacies of colonialism and nationalism, political systems and opposition, Islam in North Africa, and the Maghrib in the 21st century. Students will also meet with local experts, interact with Moroccan university students, and be able to do optional home stays with Moroccan families. Students are responsible for all travel expenses to and from Morocco, room and board costs in Morocco, and any other expenses beyond tuition. Application deadline: March 1. Enrollment limited. For further information visit the Yale Summer Session website. Tuition $6,400. Course dates: June 1 - July 6.
title: Society and Politics of North Africa
subject: SOCY

description: Offered in Dubrovnik, Croatia. Multidisciplinary study from antiquity to modernity. Students are responsible for all travel expenses to and from Dubrovnik, room and board costs in Croatia, and any other expenses beyond tuition. Must be taken in conjunction with HIST S299. description: Four weeks in New Haven, four weeks abroad. Development of proficiency in listening, speaking, reading, and writing through communicative activities rather than as a sequence of linguistic units. Use of authentic Spanish language texts, films, and videos; presentation of cultural topics. Students are responsible for all travel expenses to and from Spain or South America, costs of room and board, and all other expenses beyond tuition. Application deadline: March 1. description: Offered in Buenos Aires, Argentina.This course explores the dynamics of figurative and theatrical language through close reading of early and contemporary Spanish and Latin American dramatic texts. The selected plays reflect on the topics of gender, identity, love, politics, torture, and violence. Students participate in an acting workshop and attend live performances of Argentine theater. Prerequisite: SPAN 150 or equivalent. Students are responsible for all travel expenses to and from Buenos Aires, room and board costs in Argentina, and any other expenses beyond tuition. Application deadline: March 1. Enrollment limited. For further information visit the Yale Summer Session website. 1 Credit. Tuition $3,300.  Course dates: May 25 - June 29.
title: Theater and Poetry Workshop
subject: SPAN

description: Four weeks in New Haven, four weeks in Lima, Peru. The historical, social, and cultural development of Peru from pre-Columbian times to the present. Peruvian history; the culture and character of Peru and of its capital, Lima; architecture, art, gastronomic history, immigration, and ethnicity. Use of authentic Spanish language texts, films, music, and visual arts. Conducted in Spanish. Must be taken concurrently with SPAN S130 and S140. Prerequisite: SPAN 120 or equivalent. Prerequisite: SPAN 120 (Elementary Spanish II) or equivalent. Enrollment limited. For further information visit the Yale Summer Session website. 1 Credit. Tuition: see SPAN S130/140. Course dates: June 3 - July 27.
title: Cultural Studies of Peru
subject: SPAN

description: Four weeks in New Haven, four weeks in Bilbao. Analysis and discussion of the historical, social, and cultural development of Spain from the Civil War to the present. Use of a variety of materials, including literary texts, essays, film, television, music, and visual arts. Classes will be held in the headquarters of the University of Deusto, located opposite the statuary and facing the Guggenheim Museum. Founded in 1886, the university continues to be one of the most important institutions of higher education of the Basque Country and Spain. Students are responsible for all travel expenses to and from Bilbao, costs of room and board, and all other expenses beyond tuition. Application deadline: March 1. Must be taken in conjunction with SPAN S130 and S140. Prerequisite: SPAN 120 (Elementary Spanish II) or equivalent. Enrollment limited. For further information visit the Yale Summer Session website. 1 Credit. Tuition: see SPAN S130/140. Course dates: June 3 - July 27.
title: Spain, 1936 to the Present: History, Literature and Culture
subject: SPAN

description: Four weeks in New Haven, four weeks in Quito. Analysis and discussion of the historical, social, and cultural development of Ecuador from Pre-Columbian times to the present. Presented through a variety of materials (literary texts, essays, films, music, visual arts). Students are responsible for all travel expenses to and from Quito, costs of room and board, and all other expenses beyond tuition. Application deadline: March 1. Must be taken in conjunction with SPAN S130 and S140. Prerequisite: SPAN 120 (Elementary Spanish II) or equivalent. Enrollment limited. For further information visit the Yale Summer Session website. 1 Credit. Tuition: see SPAN S130/S140. Course dates: June 3 - July 27.
title: Ecuador from Pre-Columbian Times to Present
subject: SPAN

description: An examination of forces shaping American cities and strategies for dealing with them. Topics include housing, commercial development, parks, zoning, urban renewal, landmark preservation, new towns, and suburbs. Includes games, simulated problems, fieldwork, lectures, and discussion as well as field trips in New Haven and to New York City. 1 Credit. Tuition $3,300. Session A: June 3 - July 5.
title: Introduction to the Study of the City
subject: STCY

description: Offered at the Swahili Resource Centre in Mombasa, Kenya. Refinement of students' speaking, listening, reading, and writing skills. Prepares students for further work in literary, language, and cultural studies as well as for a functional use of Kiswahili. Study of structure and vocabulary is based on a variety of texts from traditional and popular culture. Emphasis on command of idiomatic usage and stylistic nuance. Must be taken in conjunction with SWAH S140. Prerequisite: SWAH 120b (Elementary Kiswahili II) or equivalent. Application deadline: March 1. Enrollment limited. Additional costs: $2,500 room and board in Kenya. Students are responsible for all travel expenses to and from Mombasa, and any other expenses beyond tuition. For further information contact the instructor at 203.432.9902 or at ann.biersteker@yale.edu or visit the Yale Summer Session website. Please also see www.yale.edu/macmillan/african. 1 1/2 Credits. Tuition $2,500. Course dates: June 1 - July 27.
title: Intermediate Kiswahili I
subject: SWAH

description: Offered in Mombasa, Kenya. Development of fluency through readings and discussions on contemporary topics in Kiswahili, including its origins and spread to different parts of Eastern and Central Africa. The role of Kiswahili in addressing issues such as health and the environment. Introduction to literary criticism in Kiswahili. Materials include Kiswahili oral literature, prose, poetry, and plays, as well as texts drawn from popular and political culture. Prerequisite: SWAH 140b or equivalent. Students are responsible for all travel expenses to and from Kenya, room and board costs, and any other expenses beyond tuition. Application deadline: March 1. Enrollment limited. For further information visit the Yale Summer Session website. 2 Credits. Tuition $5,000. Course dates: June 1 - July 13.
title: Advanced Kiswahili
subject: SWAH

description: Introduction to the construction and performance of heroism in Greek tragic drama, with close reading of selected plays in translation. Focus on the sagas of the House of Atreus and Oedipus. Defining the tragic hero; the tragic flaw; characterization and stagecraft; playwrights' responses to the Homeric hero; modern responses to Greek tragedy. Includes screenings of film adaptations of the plays. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,300. Session A: June 3 - July 5.
short_title: The Tragic Hero in Greek Drama
title: The Tragic Hero in Greek Drama
subject: THST

description: Global exploration of embodied ritual performance in Islam. Case studies range from ceremonies of the Mevlevi dervishes in Turkey to activist art in the context of U.S. detention and deportation of Muslims after 9/11. Development of practical skills in ethnographic research. 1 Credit. Tuition $3,300. Session A: June 3 - July 5.
title: Performance in Islamic Worlds
subject: THST

description: In-depth reading and discussion of major twentieth-century American playwrights, including Eugene O'Neill, Thornton Wilder, Zora Neale Hurston, Tennessee Williams, Arthur Miller, Edward Albee, David Mamet, and Suzan-Lori Parks. 1 Credit. Tuition $3,300. Session A: June 3 - July 5.
title: Modern American Drama
subject: THST

description: A sociological approach to the study of sex and gender, focusing on how and why these categories matter for individuals and societies. Topics include the relationship between sex and gender; sex/gender difference and competing explanations for sexual inequality; gender and work; sex and sexuality in society; masculinity, gender, and sports; and feminism. 1 Credit. Tuition $3,300. Session A: June 3 - July 5.
title: Sex and Gender in Society
subject: WGSS

description: Interdisciplinary exploration of the gendering of food production, preparation, and consumption in cross-cultural perspective. Topics include agricultural practices, cooking, pasteurization, kitchen technology, food storage, home economics, hunger, anorexia, breast-feeding, meals, and ethnic identity. Class visits to Peabody Museum, Beinecke Library, Yale Farm, and Yale University Art Gallery. 1 Credit. Tuition $3,300. Session B: July 8 - August 9.
title: Women, Food and Culture
subject: WGSS

description: Scientific and medical ideas about the natural world and the body have long been influenced by concepts of gender, even as expectations regarding gender have been shaped by scientific theories. Students will explore the historical relationship between gender and science, medicine, and technology in Western society, from the medieval and early modern period through to contemporary American debates. Students will analyze the relationship between science, medicine, and gender in order to gain historical insights and a critical perspective with regard to the structure of scientific and medical practice. Class visits to the Medical Historical Library and Peabody Museum expected. 1 Credit. Tuition $3,300. Session A: June 3 - July 5.
title: Gender in Science and Medicine
subject: WGSS
